title-group.article-title: Choanal Polyp Originating from the Middle Turbinate

body.p: A previously healthy 40-year-old man presented with nasal obstruction for 1 month. Endoscopic examination (Figure 1) and computed tomography (CT) scan revealed a choanal polyp originating from the medial side of the left middle turbinate extending through the choana into the nasopharynx posteriorly. However, all paranasal sinuses were clear. The polyp was completely removed by endoscopic surgery under local anesthesia (Figure 2). The histological diagnosis was inflammatory polyp.

caption.p: Nasal endoscopy (A) and retrovelar nasopharyngoscopy (B) show the polyp originating from the medial side of left middle turbinate extending to the nasopharynx. CP, choanal polyp; IT, inferior turbinate; MT, middle turbinate; NS, nasal septum; P, polyp; U, uvula.
There was a pedicle attached to the middle turbinate (arrow), and the polyp, measuring 6 × 4 × 2.5 cm, was completely removed.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The choanal polyp (CP) can originate from unusual locations.1,2 In particular, a CP originating from the middle turbinate with extension to the choana is an extremely rare entity, and only 3 cases have been reported so far in the English literature.1-3 Reported sites of origin were described as follows: the inferior side,1 the medial side,2 and the posterior end3 of the middle turbinate. Although varying in location, CPs present in a similar manner and share similar symptoms and histological findings. Nasal obstruction is the predominant symptom in a CP originating from the middle turbinate.1,2

The endoscopic examinations and imaging modalities are important for diagnosis.1,2 The characteristic endoscopic finding in our patient was a pedicle attached to the middle turbinate with the main mass extending to the choana. The paranasal sinus CT was helpful in making the diagnosis and detecting the site of origin, sinus involvement, and the extent of the polyp.1

Preoperative detection of the origin is important for surgical planning and for preventing recurrences.1,2 If CPs have an endoscopically proven pedicle originating from the middle turbinate without sinus involvement on CT findings, we suggest endoscopic surgery under local anesthesia as the recommended treatment. Careful endoscopic dissection and resection of all diseased mucosa surrounding the point of origin must be necessary to prevent recurrence.1,2 This manuscript received approval for publication from the institutional review board of Chung-Ang University Hospital.
